image.altText: People stand as smoke billows from a tank by a large fence

items.synopsis: The Israeli military says it is striking targets in the Gaza Strip after the Hamas militant group launched a major new operation, firing rockets into southern Israel.

title.children: 'We are at war': Palestinian militants launch new military operation, Israel strikes targets in Gaza

image.altText: High-vis workers on a cherry picker next to power lines with Perth skyline in the background

items.synopsis: Around Australia, records are tumbling as rooftop solar production soars to new highs. Experts say the trend is pushing the grid to its limits and highlighting the urgent need for storage.

title.children: Australia's solar energy output eclipses records, sparking urgent need for battery storage

image.altText: Emergency vehicles hear a burnt-out patch of grass in a field near a large gum tree.

items.synopsis: Police believe the crash near Gundaroo, north of Canberra, killed a man and three children, but the investigation will be slow and difficult.

title.children: 'Difficult undertaking': Investigators sift through burnt wreckage of plane crash that likely killed four people

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A man celebrates after scoring a try in an NRL match

items.synopsis: His 219 appearances is fourth all-time for the league's oldest club and he retired as the most prolific tryscorer in Rabbitohs history.

title.children: South Sydney great Nathan Merritt in hospital on life support

image.altText: Ashley Paul Griffith and Brett Peter Cowan

items.synopsis: Both want police to investigate the alleged assault that sent one man to hospital.

title.children: Ashley Paul Griffith and Brett Peter Cowan allegedly assaulted in prison

image.altText: Police in a car park, with fencing to obscure something.

items.synopsis: Police say a number of shots were fired outside a shopping centre in Craigieburn, in Melbourne's north, just before 3pm on Saturday.

title.children: Man shot dead, another wounded in suspected targeted attack in Melbourne car park, police say

image.altText: A Tasmanian azure kingfisher sits on a branch, below which a spider web is visible

items.synopsis: Dean has fallen in love with the elusive Tasmanian azure kingfisher, but fears not enough is being done to protect the species, which is one of 14 endangered native birds without a recovery plan.

title.children: It's estimated there are between 250 and 400 of these birds left in the wild — but there's no plan to save them

image.altText: A man behind a lecturn speaks

items.synopsis: The Russian president this week revealed more details about an experimental nuclear missile. This is what we know about it, and how successful testing has been so far.

title.children: What 'nuclear pervert' Putin's latest missile threats could mean for humanity

image.altText: Profile of man in blue jumper leaning over young girl in bed, back of his hand placed on girl's forehead to check fever.

items.synopsis: It's the middle of the night and your child's temperature is spiking. Do you reach for a washcloth to cool them down? Give them medication? Or call a doctor? Take our quiz and find out if you are doing it correctly.

title.children: Four of the biggest myths about treating fever in children busted

image.altText: woman with white curly hair looks at beach shoreline at sunset

items.synopsis: Gillian Sneddon helped put paedophile politician Milton Orkopoulos in jail, but she believes police missed opportunities to investigate before he committed more crimes.

title.children: This whistleblower stopped a paedophile politician. Now she says some of his victims could have been spared

image.altText: the prime minister anthony albanese and son nathan vote early in the october 14 indigenous referendum

title.children: 'I cast my vote for Yes': Albanese joins 1.8 million Australian pre-poll voters ahead of referendum

image.altText: A man with long hair in a polo shirt stands in front of a pyramid shaped building and flag poles.

items.synopsis: A confidential meeting of the Barkly Regional Council will be held to discuss the actions of its mayor, Jeffrey McLaughlin.

title.children: Outback mayor refusing to resign after video emerges of him pinning Indigenous boy to ground

image.altText: a big sycamore tree cut down and lying on its die on a cobbledstone wall in a  moore

items.synopsis: The loss of the Sycamore Gap tree sent a nation into grief. Rebecca Banham explores why individual trees can become important to our sense of security.

title.children: Why it feels so bad to lose the iconic Sycamore Gap tree

image.altText: An attendance figure of 25,392 flashes on the big screen during a Socceroos game at Lang Park.

items.synopsis: Football Australia has not ruled out hosting the 2034 FIFA World Cup but would need to build extra stadiums to stage the event or team up with at least two other countries.

title.children: The stadium requirement that could hamper Australia's bid to host the 2034 FIFA World Cup

image.altText: Headshots of Matt Gaetz and Kevin McCarthy.

title.children: How a sex-trafficking probe fuelled the feud between Kevin McCarthy and the man who brought him down

image.altText: Virginia Trioli in one of Melbourne's colourful laneways.

title.children: Diary of a recovering early morning adrenaline addict

image.altText: Two phones charging

items.synopsis: In the world of lithium-ion batteries, smartphones take centre stage. Yet they've also sparked an ongoing debate: does prolonged (or overnight) charging wreak havoc on your battery?

title.children: Should you charge your phone overnight? Will 'overcharging' make it explode? Common battery myths debunked

image.altText: A young man in a Hudsons Coffee uniform gives a thumbs up while leaning against a cafe counter.

items.synopsis: More businesses are recognising the benefits of employing people with disability, but "misconceptions and stereotypes" remain, a support agency says.

title.children: More businesses are becoming inclusive for people with disability, and Finn works for one of them

image.altText: Ecologist Dana Bergstrom kneels among rocks by the sea

items.synopsis: A prominent ecologist tells senators it's "too hard to do science" at the Australian Antarctic Division, revealing she quit due to advice from her dentist.

title.children: Stressed former Antarctic researcher had 'four cracked molars', quit on advice from her dentist

image.altText: A large Aboriginal flag hanging from Brisbane's Victoria Bridge over the river with the words "vote no" written across it

items.synopsis: Australians are familiar with the prominent Aboriginal faces fronting the conservative No campaign against the Voice. But there's a community-led "Vote No" campaign that hasn't captured as many headlines but aims to influence the outcome of the referendum.

title.children: A change of heart, a black no and a reluctant yes: How Aboriginal people see the Voice

image.altText: An older Indigenous lady wears a blue dress and looks upwards as she places her elbow on a fridge

items.synopsis: As debate rages in remote communities about whether a Voice to Parliament will improve the lives of Indigenous Australians, leaders in WA's northern-most town hope it can lift the next generation out of hopelessness to a place of prosperity.

title.children: 'They want jobs, not handouts': Why locals say the Voice could break a vicious cycle in this outback town

image.altText: Stan Grant

items.synopsis: The veteran journalist and former host of Q+A says the media's coverage of the Voice to Parliament referendum has been "terribly predictable".

title.children: Stan Grant says Australia's media needs a 'reckoning', in first interview since leaving the ABC

image.altText: A woman takes a selfie with a man waving his hand

items.synopsis: Mark Richardson is "back from the brink of death" and keen to get home after being medically evacuated from Bali to Darwin.

title.children: Surf coach Mark Richardson 'blown away' by support after Bali evacuation, surgery

image.altText: An Adelaide Crows AFLW player attempts to tackle a Melbourne opponent.

items.synopsis: Adelaide claims a tense 10-point win over reigning premiers Melbourne to be the only unbeaten team so far this season, while Collingwood stuns the inaccurate Brisbane Lions.

title.children: Crows beat Demons in thriller, Magpies down Lions in boilover

image.altText: Vaccination syringes and glass bottles on a yellow background

items.synopsis: Wouldn't it be handy if we could be vaccinated against influenza and COVID-19 with a single shot? Early clinical trials indicate that could be possible in a few years.

title.children: Combination COVID/flu vaccines are passing clinical trials. When can we expect them in Australia?

image.altText: A numbat with tongue sticking out

items.synopsis: Visitors to Western Australian forests are being urged not to hassle numbats — or any animal — to get a shot for social media.

title.children: Tourists warned to stop hassling endangered marsupial for selfies

image.altText: A wallaby in the bush.

items.synopsis: There are just 50 southern brush-tailed rock wallabies left in the wild. These are the people fighting to save them.

title.children: Just 50 of these animals are left in the wild. The fight to save them has spanned decades

image.altText: A sign that reads "Vote no, Don't know" outside a polling booth with volunteers handing out yes brochures

items.synopsis: After many months of bitter debate about the Voice, an address to the National Press Club this week reminds us that we are back at a point where it seems that, no matter what the truth may be, we will not let it lead to any change, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The Voice debate is yet another ugly chapter in Australia's history

image.altText: People gather on a dark pavement under the neon glow of Chinese restaurant signs.

items.synopsis: Researchers warn some Chinese Australian community members may be stuck in an information silo on WeChat, with information from the No Voice campaign saturating the social media platform.

title.children: Concerns many Chinese Australians will vote No after seeing one side of the Voice argument on WeChat

image.altText: An Indigenous musician in a tracksuit stands with one foot on a wedge and blasts a didgeridoo at a festival crowd.

items.synopsis: Some of the biggest names in Australian music have thrown high-decibel support behind the Yes campaign – with a support act in the form of Anthony Albanese – as the Voice referendum looms.

title.children: Indigenous rap royalty, rock legends unite to send one-word message as 8,500 attend Voice festival

image.altText: Young debutante with disabilities stands in the centre with a parent on each side, smiling and holding hands.

items.synopsis: Christine Davis never thought she'd see her granddaughter Kaitlan make her debut at a debutante ball, until now.

title.children: At this debutante ball, there's no customary curtsy and you can walk to the stage in your own time

image.altText: John Candy with four black actors who have their arms around each other and are standing behind a bobsled

items.synopsis: The 1993 film Cool Runnings turns 30 this week and there are some upcoming Hollywood movies with similar feel-good underdog themes.

title.children: Cool Runnings turns 30: Why people gravitated towards a film about a Jamaican bobsled team
